nodes.text: An agent who seeks to maximize the time-average growth rate of her wealth has preferences representable by a unique ergodic transformation f that makes maximizing expected f(wealth) equivalent to maximizing time-average growth

If preferences on stochastic wealth processes satisfy axioms Consistency, Archimedean, Independence, Monotonicity, and the Ergodicity Axiom then there exists a representation where x >= x' iff E[f(x_t)] >= E[f(x'_t)] and E[f(x_t)] equals the time-average growth of f(x_t) (Theorem 3.3)
Preferences are defined over stochastic wealth processes (SWPs) x = {x0, x1, ...} with filtrations Ft and agents compare entire processes rather than one-period outcomes
Under mixture-space axioms (Consistency and Independence plus Archimedean) the preference preorder on X is represented by a linear functional L(x) (Mixture Space Theorem, Theorem 3.2)
Lemma 3.1: mixture ordering properties hold and imply uniqueness of the mixture weight alpha* that makes an intermediate process indifferent to a mixture of superior and inferior processes
Growth rates defined: sample average, time-average limit, and expected rate; ergodicity means time-average equals expectation for transformed process f(xt)

Empirical motivation: Copenhagen Experiment (Meder et al. 2021) found subjects' implied utilities adapted to render changes ergodic (log utility for multiplicative dynamics, linear for additive), motivating Ergodicity Economics
Ergodicity Axiom (EA): an agent ranks two SWPs by comparing long-run time-average growth of a transformed process f, i.e. x > x' iff lim_{t->infty} (f(x_t)-f(x0))/t > same for x' (Axiom 3.5)

Consequence: when f is the ergodic transformation of an SWP, maximizing expected f(x_t) is equivalent to maximizing time-average growth rate, so the linear functional L equals expectation of f and equals the time-average growth

To obtain expectation representation one restricts to square-integrable monotonic functions (L2) and considers truncated finite-horizon SWPs xt, applying the mixture-space result at each t to define Lt and relate it to Et

Interpretation claim: the transformation f is not intrinsically a risk-preference parameter but the ergodic transformation that extracts the growth coefficient; standard risk-aversion language (e.g., gamma) is a descriptive re-interpretation when f takes familiar forms

Comparison claim: Ergodicity Economics is distinct from classical expected utility approaches and should be compared normatively to temporal/multi-period expected utility rather than static EUT; the paper axiomatizes EE to provide a basis for such comparisons

Limitations acknowledged: framework assumes objective known dynamics, relies on t -> infinity asymptotics (pre-asymptotic life ignored), and omits innate preferences for early resolution of uncertainty and model ambiguity

For Ito dynamics dx = a(x) dt + b(x) dW, an ergodic transformation f exists if df = alpha dt + beta dW with constants alpha,beta, yielding condition a(x) = (alpha/beta) b(x) + b(x) b'(x)/2 (equation 20)

Concrete derivation: for a chosen b(x)=x^gamma the ergodic f solves f'(x)=1/b(x) so f(x)=x^{1-gamma}/(1-gamma)+C, showing familiar CRRA-type transformations arise as ergodic transformations (example result)

Implication and conclusion: axiomatization pins down when agents who maximize time-average growth can be represented by expected-value maximization of a unique ergodic transform f, enabling comparisons to classical models and guiding empirical testing, but practical extensions should address ambiguity and finite-horizon preferences
